title: Time for Argos to give kicker Alix the boot
text:
BMO Field to host 2016 Grey Cup: Source 
MONTREAL — The Argos need to somehow iron out their kicking game, a necessity in three-down football when field position and momentum become paramount at this time of the season. 
It was comical to the point of embarrassment Monday afternoon at McGill Stadium, where Anthony Alix did himself no favours by falling into Scott Milanovich’s dog house. 
Three of Alix’s five first-half punts sailed out of bounds, earning flags and earning the wrath of Milanovich, who had seen enough, opting for veteran Dave Stala in the second half. 
Stala is a fill-in, by no means a full-time punter, but a coach needs to trust his player and there is none for Alix. 
The kid has a strong leg, but he’s too erratic, the Argos first exposing Alix to the CFL before releasing him. He hooked up with the RedBlacks for seven weeks before Ottawa booted Alix out of town. 
Alix did return to Ottawa for Toronto’s second win over the Redblacks, but his days in Toronto now appear over. 
Swayze Waters isn’t close to returning following his second injury of the season, but even Waters at 10% represents a better option for the Argos. 
Late in the third quarter, the Argos had Justin Palardy handle the punting duties, Toronto’s field-goal kicker who missed from 42 yards out in the opening quarter. 
Whether it’s an American, Canadian, whatever the case may be, the Argos need to do something to solidify their punting game. 
Milanovich said following his team’s win that Alix got hurt, but even healthy the days of Alix should be over in Toronto. 
“The play on special teams hurt us with field position,’’ said Milanovich. “We found a way a win and we knew it wouldn’t be easy. That’s a prideful football team. 
“It wasn’t a great performance, but we found a way to win.” 
The Argos also found a way to overcome a successful on-side kick by the Als, who took deep into Toronto’s territory before expiring, a drive kept alive by a great one-handed reception by Samuel Giguere on third down. 
Of course, had the Argos converted on a field goal attempt, the late-game drama would have been avoided. 
When teams take up a roster by going with an American, these imports, except for rare exceptions, must handle all three facets, punting, field goals and kickoffs. 
That’s what made Waters, when healthy, so valuable and as it turns out so valuable and indispensable. 
When he got hurt in the season opener, it was left up to Stala to do all three. 
The Argos then signed Ronnie Pfeffer, the kid the team should have on its roster, only the RedBlacks are hiding the Canadian on their injured list, even though he’s not hurt. 
It’s not uncommon, but it’s a tactic the CFL must end. 
It’s anyone’s guess who will punt for the Argos this Saturday against Calgary. 
On this afternoon, the Argos were lucky because the Als are quarterback poor, forced to go with all three signal-callers, but no one stepped up. 
Rakeem Cato was average before leaving with an injury. 
Anthony Boone and Tanner Marsh were as bad as Toronto’s kicking game. Sponsored Links Time for Argos to give kicker Alix the boot
